prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al., Figure 2 shows each social layer of a multi-layer network proposed in their study. The nodes in the network represent individuals, and the connections between them represent social interactions that could potentially lead to infection, with edge weights indicating the probability of transmission (ranging from 0 to 1). The first layer represents interactions within households, with groups of varying sizes that are fully connected internally. These groups do not have external connections, essentially starting as disconnected components representing individual families. The group sizes are determined based on the distribution of Argentinian family sizes in 2011, with probabilities assigned to families of different sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . In any country, a significant portion of the population must engage in economic activities, leading to interactions with others. Work is a crucial aspect of social relations, especially during an epidemic. In order to model work activities, we propose a generic layer connecting people aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of the population in Argentina. Due to the diverse range of jobs and companies, creating a precise connection rule mirroring reality is challenging. For a common scenario, we consider random groups of sizes between 5 and 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected, similar to the "home" layer shown in Fig. 2(b) with n = 100. The spread of the virus within these groups is influenced by edge weights, as discussed in Section 3.1.1. Public transport, essential in most cities, poses a significant risk for epidemic spread, given their crowded nature and constant movement. The third layer in our model represents public transport, catering to those without personal vehicles. In Argentina, around 50% of the population uses public transport daily, with varying percentages based on city size. Random groups within this layer have sizes ranging from 10 to 40, with fully connected nodes.

The nodes represent individuals who remain constant across layers, with weighted connections indicating social contact and potential infection risk based on probability values between 0 and 1. The first layer depicts home interactions, consisting of groups of varying sizes that are internally fully connected. These groups, based on the Colombian family size distribution for 2010, are isolated from each other to represent different families. The distribution considers family sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members, ensuring each family includes at least one adult. Additionally, a separate layer represents work interactions for individuals aged 18 to 59, accounting for 60% of the total population in Colombia. This layer reflects the importance of work-related social interactions in epidemic scenarios. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we delve into the importance of edge weights in determining the spread of a virus among fully connected nodes within a group. Public transportation, crucial for urban mobility, presents a high risk for epidemic transmission due to its dense and constantly moving nature. Our proposed third layer focuses on these collective transports, catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Colombia, public transport usage varies between cities, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other areas, averaging around 1.2 hours daily. We estimate that 50% of the population engages in public transport, forming random groups ranging from 10 to 40 individuals with complete internal connectivity. contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: april 24
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), the researchers analyzed the impact of various interventions on the course of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital occupancy rates. The study simulated an epidemic starting at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree, spreading over 300 days in iterations of 1 day. The researchers assumed an optimistic scenario in which individuals are informed about the virus from the outset, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on April 24 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
. The activities that remain on these layers are essential services that cannot be stopped, as well as activities that continue with increased precautionary measures despite the quarantine. In this scenario, we first examine how the β parameter affects the overall shape of the epidemic. Figure 4(a) illustrates the results for four different β values in terms of daily new cases and deaths over a period of up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates result in faster spread of the disease and a greater number of cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends more quickly due to natural immunity among those who have recovered.

When comparing the model's output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18, a better fit is achieved with a β value of 0.3. This infection rate aligns well with the current situation in which most individuals are wearing masks and taking extra precautions to prevent infection. The model shows a significant overall similarity to the real data within its standard deviation. The variance in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days may be attributed to increased testing in Brazil or a decline in isolation levels below 50% on most days in the past month. The model assumes a consistent level of isolation similar to what was initially observed after government mandates in Brazil, although data indicates that these levels are fluctuating. As a result, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may be higher than reported in the study.

Regarding the daily death toll, the average number predicted by the model is higher than the official figures. This disparity may be due to underdetection rates and fewer tests being conducted. Further investigation is needed to fully comprehend this aspect.

The simulation started with the social network in its original form, with infection probabilities. The spread of infection began at a node with a degree closest to the network's average, progressing daily for up to 300 days. Initially, a scenario was considered where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability (β) of less than 1. This initial value of β, indicating natural social distancing behaviors, was found to closely reflect the Argentinian pandemic situation. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was imposed, simulating measures taken by Argentinian provinces like Buenos Aires on March 24. During this quarantine, certain layers of social interactions were removed or reduced by 70% to a β value of 0.09. The impact of varying β values on the epidemic curve was analyzed, showing that higher infection rates led to faster spread of the disease but also to quicker resolution due to natural immunization.4.1. post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model shows a notable overall similarity within its standard deviation. The higher disparity in the number of diagnosed cases in the last ten days could be attributed to increased testing in Argentina or the consistent decrease in isolation levels (below 50% for most days in the past month). We used a fixed isolation level similar to the initial days after government decrees in Argentina, but data indicates that these levels are fluctuating. In terms of daily death toll, the average number from the models proposed is higher than the official numbers, likely due to higher underdetection rates and fewer tests being conducted. To further understand this, we compared the number of deaths in Argentina between January 1 and April 30 in 2019 and 2020, revealing a noticeable increase after February 26, the date of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina, suggesting that the actual death toll could be significantly higher than reported. Moving forward, after the initial epidemic phase, we explore four potential actions that can be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) maintain current isolation levels; b) return to normal activities by ending isolation; c) resume only work activities; or d) increase isolation by ceasing remaining work and transport activities.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital beds utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The study highlighted the limitations of testing due to a low number of tests or the quick spreading velocity, resulting in only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases being diagnosed.Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).Following the first confirmed case 27 days ago, initial isolation measures were implemented, including the closure of schools and religious activities. Work and transportation continued at a reduced capacity of 30%, which helped decrease the spread of the virus. Options for future actions were considered after 90 days since the first case, including maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, fully reopening activities, or only reopening work activities. The results showed that maintaining current isolation levels could lead to prolonged propagation, with an estimated peak around June 5. This scenario could result in an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, with a total of 946,830 diagnosed cases and 149,438 deaths by the end of the year. Hospitals may reach maximum capacity by June 11, but efficient implementation of ICU beds and patient management could help control the situation. It is important to note that social isolation levels in Argentina have remained low, around 12%, which may impact the effectiveness of continued isolation measures.

The study acknowledges limitations in testing capacity due to the low number of tests available and the rapid spread of the virus. Only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases are assumed to be diagnosed, with asymptomatic cases going undetected and continuing to spread the virus. The study also assumes that mild cases, even if undiagnosed, will self-isolate at home while severe and critical cases will be hospitalized and fully isolated from the network.

Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and

After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of

author: chunwei
pre_context: In the article published in the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health in 2021, an arbitrary constant κ is used in the formula m(t) = βs - βc 1 + e^-k(-t+t0) + βc. This equation employs a modified logistic function to represent the transition from infection levels before to after the implementation of full compliance with mask wearing, with values of βs = 1 and βc = 0.4, respectively. The parameter t0 represents the days after the first recorded case when mandatory mask wearing measures were enforced. For instance, in the case of Malaysia, t0 was set to 89 days since the mandatory mask policy began 89 days after the first confirmed case. This model is applied to both Scenario 1 and Scenario 3. To account for the gradual decline in universal mask compliance, Equation (9) is adjusted as follows: m(t) = βs - βc 1 + e^-k1(-t+t0) + βc - βnc 1 + e^-k2(-t+t1) + βnc. As individuals become more complacent and fatigued during the pandemic, the infection rate βnc increases slowly due to noncompliance. This gradual increase in noncompliance is in contrast to the immediate impact of compulsory mask enforcement on reducing infection rates.This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. Figure 2 illustrates one such example, where we have βnc = 0.5 and

6. Results and Discussion
6.1. Dynamics of Delay in Compulsory Mask Wearing
Using SEIR models for the scenarios outlined above, we calculated the Maximum Infected Values by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. In the most basic scenario (Scenario 1) with complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, the impact of mask enforcement delays was analyzed. Figure 3 illustrates the outcomes when mask wearing was enforced (a) on the day of Malaysia's first COVID-19 case detection; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not at all. The earlier the enforcement of mask wearing, the lower the Maximum Infected Value and the longer it took to reach this maximum value. The Infected compartment curve shifted to the right, with a lower maximum value, before declining. This peak is known as the Maximum Infected Value.

When applying SEIR models to the scenarios described above, the Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing can be observed. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance throughout the duration of mask enforcement and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the cases where mask wearing was enforced on different days: (a) the day the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not enforced at all. 

As shown in Figure 3, earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the number of days taken to reach this maximum. The maxima of the Infected compartment shifts to the right, indicating a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The number of infected cases increases until reaching a global maximum, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models. This global maximum is known as the Maximum Infected Value. 

For instance, in the case of (a) no delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is about 10.453% and the peak occurs on day 291 after the first case was detected. With a (b) 50-day delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, with the peak occurring on day 195. With a (c) 100-day delay, the maximum infected value significantly increases to around 27.474%, and the peak occurs much earlier on day 103. text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The preprint of the article titled "An agent-based epidemic model REINA for COVID-19 to identify destructive policies" was posted on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint, which has not been peer-reviewed, and has granted medRxiv permission to display it perpetuity under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The study highlights the varied policies adopted by countries in responding to the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments, allowing for interventions such as physical isolation, testing and tracing, and controlling the number of cases entering the area to be implemented over a timeline. The open-source code for the model is available online. Results are based on the demographics of the Helsinki University Hospital region (1.6 million inhabitants), with the modeling starting on 2020-02-18 and strategies following the actual situation until 2020-04-06 before diverging. The default mitigation scenario aims to slow down the spread of the epidemic, with a variable strategy focusing on hospital capacity, mobility restrictions, testing, tracing, and isolating coronavirus positive patients and contacts. Please note that this research has not yet undergone peer review and should not be used to guide clinical practice.

author: chunwei
pre_context: This version of the preprint was posted on April 17, 2020 and can be found at https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint, which has not been peer-reviewed, and has granted medRxiv a license to display it indefinitely under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the model of the coronavirus agent, showing different agent states, transitions between states, infection pathways, and population subgroups targeted for isolation or mobility restrictions. The model includes an incubating state where individuals have the virus but do not yet show symptoms. The healthcare system parameters considered are the number of hospital beds, intensive care beds, testing methods (lazy, active, aggressive), number of tests conducted daily, and length of testing queue. The model also divides the infectious state into four sub-states for analysis.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model logs all interactions of infected agents, allowing for evaluation of various testing and tracing strategies. The latest version of the model can test symptomatic agents and conduct contact tracing with a user-adjustable level of accuracy. (Tuomisto et al., REINA model and destructive policies 2020-04-08, p. 6/29)

text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Study on Assessing the Transmission Risk of 2019-nCoV and Its Impact on Public Health Interventions, conducted by Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu from various institutions in China and Canada.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context:
The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions like intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk. The impact of travel restrictions imposed by Wuhan on 2019-nCoV infection in Beijing is nearly equivalent to increasing quarantine by a baseline value of 100 thousand. It is crucial to evaluate how costly and resource-intensive measures implemented by Chinese authorities can contribute to preventing and controlling the 2019-nCoV infection, as well as determining their optimal duration. The most stringent measures are expected to cause the outbreak to peak within two weeks (since January 23, 2020) at a significantly low level. Implementing travel restrictions (no imported exposed individuals to Beijing) could lead to a 91.14% decrease in the number of infected individuals in Beijing within seven days, compared to scenarios without such restrictions. Key words: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model.

Introduction:

Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses belonging to the Coronaviridae family. They typically cause mild respiratory infections but can sometimes be deadly. Major outbreaks caused by highly pathogenic coronaviruses have occurred in recent decades, including the SARS outbreak in 2003 in China, the MERS outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia, and the 2015 MERS outbreak in South. text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Respiratory infections exhibit significant variation in intensity and transmission range across different regions due to the uneven distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors that either facilitate or hinder pathogen spread. This geographic variability is crucial to consider given the unequal distribution of healthcare system capacity, which can significantly impact disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately affected certain regions of the United States, with the Northeast reporting higher cases and fatalities. The reasons for these regional disparities are not yet fully understood.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context:
Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal trends of the COVID-19 pandemic in correlation with healthcare capacity distribution in Ohio. 

In order to achieve this, we created a spatial mathematical model that mimics the transmission dynamics of COVID-19, taking into account geographic connectivity information at the county level. The model, known as the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, categorizes the population into different groups - susceptible, confirmed infections, hospitalized and ICU admitted, recovered, and deceased. 

Drawing from previous research that highlighted the significance of local air hubs and main roads in COVID-19 hospitalizations and mortality rates, we divided the SIHRD COVID-19 model into four spatial risk groups based on connectivity index for each county. These risk groups include counties with high passenger traffic airports, counties surrounding airport counties, counties with major highways, and counties with minimal airport or highway exposure.

The model simulated disease transmission and infection progression using seven epidemiological compartments for each spatial group, with susceptible individuals facing varying hazard rates for exposure depending on their group and the current time, reflecting the fluctuating risk of exposure and effectiveness of public health measures.

pre_context:
Counties in Ohio with higher air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of infection compared to nearby counties with high road connectivity and more isolated rural counties. The severity of the COVID-19 epidemic in different counties was not only influenced by population distribution but also by spatial attributes such as transport connectivity. More than 47% of confirmed COVID-19 cases in Ohio were concentrated in five counties (Lake Erie, Franklin County, Nolan, Birmingham, Mountain Top) with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and are local air hubs with airports that see over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The influx of travelers in these counties can lead to imported infections, fueling local transmission of the virus and accelerating its spread in these areas.

In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context:
.

In contrast, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are located in rural and less connected counties, with 10 beds per 100,000 people. Despite these disparities, our analysis indicates that the lower transmission rates in these areas prevented critical care capacity from being overwhelmed. If non-pharmaceutical interventions continued past early May, only 27% of the state's maximum ICU capacity would be reached, with three additional counties projected to exceed 50% capacity. However, easing interventions by 50% would result in reaching 61% of the state's maximum capacity, particularly impacting areas with higher disease transmission. These counties, although having higher capacity, would see capacity almost fully saturated eight weeks after easing of restrictions. In contrast, less connected rural counties would experience slower spread, protecting critical care capacity.

pre_context: The analysis found that the severity of the COVID-19 epidemic in counties in Michigan was not solely due to population distribution, but also related to factors such as transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five densely populated counties with high air traffic, leading to a higher infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties serve as local air hubs, receiving millions of passengers annually, potentially facilitating the importation of infections and accelerating local transmission. In contrast, the 31 rural and less connected counties in Michigan experienced lower rates of infection. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Michigan, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a rate of 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people. In contrast, only 7% of the total number of ICU beds available in the state are distributed in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas of the state, with a
post_context: . Despite variations in healthcare capacity among different areas of the state, our research indicates that rural and less connected counties experienced lower levels of disease transmission, preventing critical care response from becoming overwhelmed in those regions. Maintaining non-pharmaceutical interventions implemented in mid-March 2020 until early May would result in only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity being reached, excluding 10 counties without ICU beds. However, if interventions were relaxed by 50%, an estimated 61% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity would be reached within eight weeks. Counties with higher disease transmission rates would reach capacity faster, with Group 1 experiencing a 94% saturation of critical care capacity within the same time frame. In contrast, Group 4, consisting of rural and less connected counties, would see a slower spread of infection and a lower impact on critical care response.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases were analyzed using spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models in a study by D.F. Cuadros et al. The results showed that counties in Group 4 had a significantly lower critical care response compared to counties in Group 1. This lower response reduces the likelihood of critical care saturation in these areas, with only 55% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity expected to be reached eight weeks after the easing of social distancing interventions. It was also found that eight of the 31 counties in Group 4 do not have hospitals with ICU beds, while counties like Adams, Champaign, and Seneca would reach over 60% of their maximum critical care capacity. As a result, these less connected counties, along with local air hub counties, were identified as high priority areas for strengthening critical care responses to COVID-19 in Ohio.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.Nevertheless, isolated outbreaks have the potential to play a crucial role in spreading the disease and could strain local critical care capacity in affected areas. Additionally, the SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed in this study was calibrated using data exclusively from Ohio. The COVID-19 pandemic is characterized by varying intensities of sub-epidemics, even within individual countries. Outbreaks of COVID-19 have occurred at different times in various locations across the U.S. (Desjardins et al., 2020; Hohl et al., 2020), with each state implementing different control measures at different stages, leading to significant differences in disease dynamics. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the model's performance using data from diverse locations. Despite these limitations, this study presents one of the initial spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission, aiming to simulate spatial variations in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, total hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and other health metrics.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Different responses to the pandemic were adopted by various US states and national governments despite facing similar circumstances. Simulation-based epidemic models have the potential to help make well-informed decisions by predicting outcomes tailored to specific locations. By adjusting interventions virtually and observing projected results, the best course of action can be determined. However, the accuracy of epidemic models is limited due to uncertainties in input parameters and the potential for exponential growth. Small variations in parameters can lead to significant differences in predicted case numbers, causing criticisms of inaccurate estimates. This article discusses how simulation models can still aid in the selection of COVID-19 interventions, as demonstrated through a case study of their use in designing interventions at Cornell University. A modeling framework is also presented that can assist in decision-making at other universities.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our research influenced the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020 and helped shape an asymptomatic screening program that continues to be vital to Cornell's overall strategy. Following our modeling recommendations, a surveillance program was implemented inviting all students back to campus in the 2020-2021 school year under an asymptomatic screening program, with 75% of students returning. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing with less-sensitive but more-comfortable anterior nares (AN) sampling based on our modeling findings. Cornell implemented this program through a collaborative effort with a local health care provider and by establishing a new COVID-19 testing laboratory. Our modeling recommendations also guided adjustments in testing frequency for specific groups in the spring 2021 semester and in response to the Delta variant and changes in social distancing policies in fall 2021. Despite these challenges, Cornell reported fewer than 1,044 infections among students and employees during the 2020-2021 academic year, fewer than many other schools with similar student populations. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying input parameters that can effectively control epidemics, guiding decisions on testing strategies and public health measures.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: We selected a prior probability distribution over parameters by using independent normal distributions for each parameter. The mean and variance of the prior for each parameter were chosen to result in a symmetric 95% Bayesian credible interval that aligned with plausible ranges for each parameter. Utilizing a multivariate normal distribution as a prior was necessary for modeling and tractability reasons. We needed a unimodal prior with ellipsoidal contours for the analysis that followed, making the multivariate normal the ideal choice. Random sets of parameters were drawn from this Bayesian prior, with values appropriately truncated to ensure feasibility, particularly for parameters known to be positive or bounded. Simulations were run for each set of parameters, creating a prior distribution over infections while considering parameter uncertainty. Our findings suggest that 2×/wk testing is generally effective for infection control, but large outbreaks could occur under certain parameter settings. To better understand how interventions like testing can impact robustness to parameter uncertainty, we developed a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations with varying levels of pessimism regarding the number of infections. These methods are detailed in the results and supplementary information.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.The "pessimistic (residential)" label in our plots distinguishes this scenario from one that is pessimistic about a different outcome in Results D. This pessimistic scenario significantly alters key parameters such as asymptomatic ratio, transmission rate, test sensitivity, and contact tracing effectiveness relative to a nominal scenario. These changes have the biggest impact on infections. Comparing infections under various pessimistic scenarios to infection medians drawn from the prior suggests our assumption of linearity had minimal effect on the level of pessimism in our scenarios. Simulated infections using biweekly testing at different levels of pessimism show that testing can effectively control infections, but in some cases, infection numbers can exceed 1,000, especially in highly pessimistic scenarios. Additional testing reduces this risk, with infections remaining low even at high levels of pessimism. Plots of infections and testing frequency were shared in public reports and at meetings, including nominal and pessimistic scenarios similar to those described here.

author: enrique
pre_context: We conducted a Bayesian analysis to investigate the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate in the upcoming fall 2021 semester. Our analysis utilized data from the previous academic year and information on vaccine effectiveness against the Delta variant. We adjusted transmission rates in our model for the Delta variant and factored in the effectiveness of vaccines on transmission and susceptibility to infection. Most of the Cornell student population was assumed to be vaccinated, and new international students were also getting vaccinated. Several changes had occurred since the previous semester, including the lifting of social distancing restrictions and changes in prevalence outside the campus. We incorporated these uncertainties into our model and used a joint prior to sample parameters, run simulations, and update the posterior. While there is uncertainty in individual parameters, the overall product of these parameters is more certain. Fig. 6 illustrates the marginal posteriors of each parameter.Fall 2021 modeling. (A) Marginal posterior distribution for the key parameters. Vaccine susceptibility and vaccine transmission are multipliers on the probability of becoming infected given exposure and the probability of infecting, respectively, compared to interaction between an unvaccinated source and exposed individual. The contact rate multiplier,
post_context: , and contact tracing effectiveness parameters are all multipliers on the calibrated 2020–2021 parameters.(B) The estimated total number of infections for different student vaccination rates (50%, 75%, and 100%) throughout the semester compared with the average number of tests per student per week, using a selection of Pareto-optimal testing strategies. This information was taken from a study by Frazier et al. on COVID-19 reopening decisions in college settings, focusing on Cornell University as a case study. Source: https://www.pnas.org, accessed on December 2, 2023.

author: enrique
pre_context: It is projected that by the end of 2021, approximately 680,000 people in Ontario will have been infected with COVID-19, with half of them being asymptomatic. The highest increase in cumulative infections occurred in December 2021 and March 2021, corresponding to peaks in new case counts. By the end of the year, 71% of the population will have received at least one dose of the vaccine, and 57% will be fully vaccinated. It is estimated that 11,000 individuals will have died from COVID-19 by the end of 2021, with 36% from the wild type strain, 47% from the Alpha variant, and 17% from the Delta variant. These predictions are within 10% of the actual reported data. The susceptible population decreases significantly after December 2021 due to vaccine distribution, with only 37% susceptible by the end of June 2021. The number of active infections peaks at the end of 2021 and again at the end of spring, driven by the wild-type and Alpha variants. The Alpha-driven wave accounts for 0.7% of the total population but decreases as vaccination rates increase. The infections are evenly split between asymptomatic and symptomatic cases, with the majority of cases being unvaccinated. The recovered population is expected to reach 7% of the total population by the end of 2021. These dynamics are summarized as fractions of the population that are susceptible, vaccinated, infected, and recovered, as shown in Fig. 3i. Sensitivity analysis. To identify the strongest determinants of the pandemic severity, we assess the sensitivity of model predictions to variations in key model parameters. We first conduct a sensitivity analysis in a simplified model that represents only the wild-type SARS-CoV-2, for the year 2021, but with

pre_context: Figure 2 displays the number of new infections for each virus, depicted as 7-day averages from January 1, 2021, to December 31, 2021. It also shows the cumulative count of asymptomatic and symptomatic infections for all viruses, as well as the percentage of the population vaccinated with at least one dose and both doses.(d) Cumulative deaths from each of the viruses cause. Small variations in these four parameters (5%) result in changes in the number of infections and deaths that are an order of magnitude larger; see Fig. 4.
post_context: affects the number of infected individuals who are alive and can participate in the spread of the disease.Given the significant impact of health care infrastructure on COVID-19 mortality rates, we varied the parameter for this factor by 50%. This resulted in immediate changes in the number of deaths, but compared to other aspects of SARS-CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect as less than 5% of infected individuals die. Various provincial policies and interventions were considered, including non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI) to reduce disease infectivity, vaccination rate, dosing intervals, and vaccine escape rate. NPI had a large impact on the model predictions, while vaccination rate also played a significant role in controlling the spread of the disease. The dosing interval and vaccine escape rate had smaller effects and were varied by 50% due to their importance. Results indicate that effective vaccine deployment is crucial in combating a pandemic, even if the vaccine has a higher escape rate. Prioritizing the first vaccine dose by increasing the dosing interval could be beneficial in cases of limited vaccine supply. Sensitivity analyses were also conducted for all three variants, with key parameters increased to assess their effects on infections and deaths. This further emphasized the importance of vaccination rate in reducing the impact of the disease.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Figure 2 illustrates the number of new infections for various viruses as 7-day averages from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021. It also displays cumulative asymptomatic and symptomatic infections, the percentage of the population vaccinated with one or both doses, and cumulative deaths from each virus. Minor fluctuations in these factors (5%) can lead to significant changes in infection rates and fatalities, as depicted in Figure 4. The COVID-19 mortality rate impacts the number of infected individuals who can continue to spread the disease. Because COVID-19 mortality rate can vary substantially depending on health care infrastructure, we varied μW I by 50%. As expected, changes in μW I are immediately reflected in the number of deaths. However, compared to other clinical features of SARS- CoV-2, the mortality rate has a relatively small effect on the infected population, since < 5% of them die (Fig. 4). Provincial policy and pharmaceutical interventions that were considered include NPI that reduce the effective disease infectivity (via scaling by λ),
post_context: delay between the first and second vaccine doses (ω2, PZ and ω2, AZ, varied simultaneously), and vaccine escape rate (βW V). The variables λ and ω1 are changed by 5%, leading to significant effects on model predictions for NPI modeled by scaling βW directly. The impact of the vaccination rate on disease spread is also significant, though less than λ and ω1. Dosing interval (ω2) and vaccine escape rate (βW V) have smaller effects but were varied by 50% due to the wide variation in dosing intervals within the population and the lack of thorough characterization of vaccine escape rates. Among these factors, effective vaccine deployment (represented by ω1) is crucial in combating a pandemic, as shown in the vaccine-related results. Prioritizing the first dose and lengthening the dosing interval may be advisable if vaccine supply is limited, as demonstrated in Canada. A sensitivity analysis considering all three variants and key model parameters showed that certain parameters, such as βX R and ηR, which mediate VOC interactions, have different values for each variant. Simulations were conducted by varying each parameter value for individual variants separately to assess their effects on the number of infections and deaths. These include βX (X = W, A, or D), σX, αX, γX, and ω1 being increased by 5%, λ by 10%, and μI by 4 folds.

author: enrique
pre_context: The sensitivity of model predictions, specifically the total number of infections and deaths, to changes in model parameter values is examined in a two-year simulation involving interactions with variant dynamics. Parameters are individually adjusted for wild-type, Alpha, and Delta variants. The relative changes in infections and deaths are then calculated for each variant. Parameters considered include virus infectivity, rate of infection from different variants, ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic infections, increased infectivity of asymptomatic individuals compared to symptomatic ones, mortality rate, recovery rate, loss of immunity, vaccine escape rate, NPI stringency, dosing interval, and vaccination rate. The baseline model assumes a distribution of Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines based on Ontario statistics, but what if a larger proportion of vaccines were AstraZeneca, as seen in the UK? One key distinction between the two vaccine types is that Pfizer offers stronger protection against all variants, particularly Delta, after one or two doses.For instance, an individual having received both doses of the Pfizer vaccine is 88% protected against the Delta variant, whereas with the AstraZeneca vaccine the protection is only at 60%19. We conduct a simulation in which only 40% of the vaccines are Pfizer. With a larger portion of the vaccinated population now under reduced vaccine protection, the spread of the VOC is substantially accelerated. By December 31, 2021, the model predicts
post_context: , more than three times higher than the baseline prediction of 234 new Delta infections a day (Fig. 7a).The total number of Delta infections and related deaths are expected to increase significantly by December 31, 2021, reaching 62K and 882 respectively, compared to baseline values of 39K and 689. If the vaccination rate in the province decreases, with only 67% of the population being vaccinated by September 1, 2021, compared to the baseline of 74%, the total number of infections and deaths due to Delta variant would rise by 75% by March 2022. Ontario began to reopen gradually starting in mid-June 2021, with in-person classes planned to resume in September. The baseline model assumes that the remaining non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPI) still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%. However, considering the possibility of pandemic fatigue and increased personal interactions, as well as potential outbreaks in schools, we explore a scenario where NPI measures are less stringent starting from fall 2021 (September 1), with λ increasing from its baseline value of 0.4.

During the period, we observed an increasing trend in the number of diagnosed individuals. Specifically, the diagnosis rate, dI(t), was found to be inversely related to time t, with a formula that includes parameters such as dI0 (initial diagnosis rate), dIf (fastest diagnosis rate), and r2 (exponential decreasing rate). These parameters are crucial in assessing the availability of resources in the epicenter. By adapting a previously derived formula to incorporate time-dependent coefficients reflecting evolving public health interventions and resources, we defined a(t) as the effective daily reproduction ratio, which measures the daily reproduction number of new infections caused by a single infected individual during their infectious period. Our data was collected from the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China, providing information on cumulative confirmed cases, deaths, recoveries, and newly confirmed cases reported on a daily basis.

Due to the lockdown of Hubei on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions have been implemented nationwide and advancements in coronavirus detection technologies have increased case confirmation efficiency. With the adoption of stringent prevention and control measures and improved detection and treatment in China, the previously calculated basic reproduction number may no longer accurately predict the epidemic trend in the near future. Therefore, we have updated our data to parameterize the model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-estimate the transmission risk of 2019-nCov. By analyzing the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) as shown in Fig. 1(a), we are able to calculate the effective daily reproduction ratio, η(t).

As a result of strict prevention measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has been below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decline in new infections. The effective daily reproduction ratio decreased from January 23rd, 2020 to January 25th, 2020, as a result of various restrictive measures. This includes the lockdown of Hubei, contact tracing, and subsequent quarantine and isolation steps.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In comparison to the results shown in Figure 2, we observed an increase in projected cumulative confirmed cases and a delayed peak time. In a previous publication (Tang et al., 2020), we calculated a reproduction number of 6.47 (95% CI 5.71e7.23), which is higher than previous estimates. For example, the WHO estimated a reproduction number of 1.4e2.5, while Li et al. (2020) calculated a slightly higher value of 2.2 (95% CI 1.4 to 3.9). Various mathematical models, whether pre-prints or peer-reviewed, have reported reproduction numbers ranging from 1.3 to 4.7. Two studies in the literature have suggested an underestimation of coronavirus cases: one by Zhao et al. (2020) and another by Read et al. (2020). Zhao et al. (2020) quantitatively analyzed the underreporting rate of coronavirus cases and estimated 469 underreported cases (95% CI 403e540), resulting in a basic reproduction number of 2.56 (95% CI 2.49e2.63). In a previous version of their study, the reproduction number was estimated to range between 3.30 (95% CI 2.73e3.96) and 5.47 (95% CI 4.16e7.10).The basic reproduction number was also found to be associated with 0-folde2-fold increase in the reporting rate. More in detail, with report rates increasing over the time, the mean value was statistically likely to be higher than 3 but less than 5. Zhang and Wang (Zhang & Wang, 2020), employing a Bayesian framework to infer time-calibrated phylogeny from 33 available genomic sequences, found that the time of the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) was December 17th, 2019 (95% highest posterior density interval from December 7th, 2019 to December 23rd, 2019) and that the value of the
post_context: .The discrepancies in findings may be attributed to various methodological factors, such as differing assumptions, parameters, models (such as stochastic versus deterministic, compartmental versus IDEA), datasets, and estimation periods. Comparing updated versions of these studies reveals varying reproduction numbers, reflecting the evolving transmission dynamics of the coronavirus outbreak and case reporting. In particular, the reproduction number tended to rise over time alongside increasing case numbers, with results being particularly sensitive to the estimation period and data availability. It is important to note that the accuracy of model frameworks and data analysis techniques plays a significant role in these findings.

text: By using time-dependent contact and diagnose rates we refit our proposed dynamics transmission model to the data available until January 29th, 2020 and re-estimated the daily reproduction number, which implies the evolving transmission risk.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on the SARS outbreak have influenced the development of disease modeling techniques. Similar to SARS, the current 2019 n-Cov situation involves a high basic reproduction number within the epicenter of Wuhan, with a large population and extensive travel networks. The outbreak is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, Hubei province, and across China. The success of control measures depends on resources allocated to frontline workers and infected patients, as well as the speed of diagnosing and hospitalizing confirmed cases, impacting the peak value and time of the outbreak.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of an epidemic and determining the peak time requires real-time data and a thorough understanding of how to implement and utilize available resources for major public health interventions, not just policy and decision-making. This research was supported by grants from the National Natural Science Foundation of China, the Canada Research Chair Program, and the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada. We acknowledge the support from the Tianyuan Mathematical Center in Northwest China, the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences, and the Mathematics for Public Health Laboratory. References include studies on the novel Wuhan coronavirus, SARS outbreak control strategies, and transmissibility of 2019-nCoV.

text: large-eddy simulations of the ascent of a buoyant meltwater plume after its escape from beneath an Antarctic ice shelf.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Please paraphrase the following content, while keeping the core message and the length intact.JULY 2021 A R N S C H E I D T E T A L . 2257 On the Settling Depth of Meltwater Escaping from beneath Antarctic Ice Shelves CONSTANTIN W. ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the important role of localized variability in stratification in explaining the observed interannual variability in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier in Antarctica. Given the significant differences in mass loss rates and environmental conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, incorporating dynamic parameters for meltwater settling depth is essential for accurately simulating high-latitude climate in a warming world. In this paper, we discuss how such parameterization can be developed based on our findings and identify the remaining challenges. KEYWORDS: Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change 

Introduction
One notable deficiency in global coupled climate models included in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project phase 5 (CMIP5; Taylor et al. 2012) has been their inability to accurately reproduce key observed trends in the Southern Ocean, such as surface cooling, surface freshening, and sea ice expansion (Turner et al. 2013; Jones et al. 2016; Kostov et al. 2018). The Antarctic meltwater anomaly has been increasing over recent decades, potentially influencing these trends (Rye et al. 2020). Current climate models often overlook the impact of this freshwater anomaly resulting from net mass loss from the Antarctic ice sheet, which has been on the rise, reaching around 500 Gt yr 2019 (Paolo et al. 2015; Rignot et al. 2019). Recent studies suggest that incorporating this meltwater anomaly into climate models could help resolve the disparities between observations and simulations, shedding light on the observed trends (Bintanja et al. 2013; Rye et al. 2014; Bintanja et al. 2015; Rye et al. 2020). The inclusion of Antarctic glacial meltwater could have significant implications for modeling climate change.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.Results from simulating different scenarios show that ignoring social distancing and hygiene measures can have disastrous effects on the human population. The model demonstrates that implementing quarantine for contacts and isolating cases can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. This study aims to develop a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict COVID-19 epidemic dynamics and evaluate various intervention strategies to reduce the risk of the epidemic. Numerous researchers have explored mathematical modeling of the novel coronavirus, utilizing models from other respiratory illnesses like MERS-CoV to estimate transmission rates under different intervention measures.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is labeled as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t). Research has shown that the COVID-19 virus can be transmitted in two ways: from human to human and from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t) infected individuals spread the virus to susceptible individuals S(t) they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals sneeze or cough without taking necessary precautions, the virus can spread to the environment. As the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for several days, individuals in close contact with this environment are at a higher risk of exposure, especially in the early days of the outbreak before hygiene protocols are put in place. The disease spreads as susceptible individuals first move to the exposed population E(t) due to an incubation period. The exposed individuals then move to either the asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infectious population. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens present during human interaction at time t. Most infectious individuals recover and move to the recovered human population R(t). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and the pathogens in the environment is presented in Fig. 1, with the parameters used in the COVID-19 transmission model outlined in Table 1. This model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations shown in Fig. 1 as the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission.

In our proposed model, we suggest new infections occurring through interactions with infectious individuals and the environment. The interaction proportions indicate the frequency of infection transmission from susceptible individuals. Equilibrium points and the basic reproduction number of the SEIR-P model are determined by solving relevant equations. text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study in Table 1 reveals that individuals with symptoms (IS) are considered more contagious than those who are asymptomatic (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and during commutes. This results in a spike in virus cases in environments like workplaces, schools, and public transport, as shown in Figure 2b, with more confirmed cases between 10 and 35 days, as indicated in Figure 2a. In this model, the constants α1 and α2 represent the frequency at which individuals acquire the virus from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. Figure 2 demonstrates that with α1 = 0.05, the risk of contracting the virus from a contaminated environment is higher, leading to an increase in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, with α2 = 0.05, the risk of getting infected from an individual is higher, resulting in a rapid decrease in susceptible individuals by the 23rd day, as depicted in Figure 2c for α2 = 0.05. The rapid infection of many people is shown in Figures 2d-f during the duration of 0-20 days.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention in serology through immunity shielding involves the use of Table 1 to summarize policies for preventing transmission. The background includes three categories: susceptible, infectious, and recovered individuals. Recovery status is determined by the presence or absence of virus and antibodies.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.While questions remain about the length and effectiveness of immunity, strategically identifying and deploying recovered individuals presents an opportunity to decrease transmission for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing initiatives is essential for proactive measures to end the COVID-19 pandemic and allow for economic re-engagement, resulting in fewer than 25% of the population being infected compared to the expected ~90% without shielding. Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for application to COVID-19, capturing the conservative benefits of shielding. However, more complex mixing and substitution models could produce variations, particularly in spatially explicit areas or networks. In this analysis, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, simplifying by excluding births and other causes of death. The population is categorized as susceptible (S), exposed (E), infectious asymptomatically (Ia), infectious symptomatically (Is), and recovered (R) who can move freely in a 'business as usual' scenario. A portion of symptomatic cases will require hospitalization, divided into subacute (Ihsub) and critical and/or acute (requiring ICU intervention, Ihcri) cases, with a significant proportion of critical cases resulting in death. Age-specific hospitalization and acute case risks are derived from previous studies modeling potential outcomes in the United Kingdom and the United States. The comprehensive model incorporating shield immunity differs from traditional SIR models with social distancing (see Methods and Extended Data Fig. 2).

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The main focus of controlling the spread of COVID-19 has been through mitigation and suppression efforts, but questions arise regarding their sustainability and exit strategies. In addition to these measures, a 'shield immunity' model using serological tests to identify recovered individuals with protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 has been proposed. Serological testing is crucial in finding those who have immunity to the virus, leading to decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths through enhanced interactions with recovered individuals. While our predictions are based on certain assumptions, it is important to identify seropositive individuals and incorporate their behavior into intervention strategies to effectively control the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Here, we utilize our shield immunity model to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic. We simplify by excluding births and other causes of death and focus on a population consisting of susceptible, exposed, infectious asymptomatic, infectious symptomatic, and recovered individuals in a scenario without restrictions. We anticipate a significant portion of critical cases will result in fatalities. Age-specific risks for hospitalization and acute cases are derived from previous studies on outcomes in the United Kingdom and the United States. Our model, incorporating shield immunity, differs from traditional SIR models with interventions like social distancing or case isolation.Transmission rates are reduced based on the population fraction in the circulating baseline and the total number of recovered individuals between ages 20 and 60. Only a subset of recovered individuals can facilitate interaction substitutions. The model assumes that individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients. Shielding and shield immunity play key roles in this framework.

In a flexible shielding scenario, the interaction rates of recovered individuals are increased by a factor of (1 + α) compared to other individuals, while maintaining the total contact rate at the baseline level. post_context: 2:38 and other measures were implemented.The results presented in Figure 3 compare the impact of different shielding interventions on epidemic outcomes compared to a baseline scenario. Results indicate that shielding alone has the potential to reduce the overall burden of an epidemic, including decreasing total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 individuals, our model predicts 71,000 deaths in the baseline scenario for high-transmission settings, compared to 58,000 deaths with intermediate shielding and 20,000 deaths with enhanced shielding. Similarly, in low-transmission scenarios, the model predicts 50,000 deaths in the baseline scenario compared to 34,000 with intermediate shielding and 8,300 with enhanced shielding. The majority of deaths occur in individuals aged 60 years and older, despite their lower representation in the population. This is consistent with findings from other studies on COVID-19. While our simulation focuses solely on the effects of shielding, ongoing restrictions such as social distancing will further reduce interactions and transmission rates. The effectiveness of shielding depends on factors like the number of potential shields identified and their substitutability, suggesting that populations with more recovered individuals may benefit more from shielding. Additionally, demographic distributions, asymptomatic transmission rates, and immunity duration all play a role in the population-scale effects of shielding.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.

We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we assessed the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our analysis indicates that without any interventions, over 14 million individuals would have died by May 17, 2020. Starting interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. Mass gathering restrictions and school closures showed the highest reductions in infection rates at 29.6% and 17.3%, respectively. The most effective policy, stay-at-home orders, reduced infection rates by an average of 74.4% in countries that implemented it. We also illustrate how DELPHI can forecast future COVID-19 cases under different government policies and discuss how Janssen Pharmaceuticals used this information to select trial locations for their vaccine candidate. The full details and additional material can be found at the provided link.

pre_context: Li et al. (2022) conducted a study on forecasting COVID-19 under government interventions, which was published in Operations Research. The study analyzed the implementation length and effectiveness of different policy categories worldwide. The results showed that the most extensive policy implemented was the stay-at-home order, which led to a significant decrease in the residual infection rate. The study also found that more stringent policies tend to be implemented later but are associated with larger decreases in the infection rate compared to less restrictive policies.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. The effective reproduction rate, Rt, is crucial in controlling epidemics, as it should be less than 1 for effective mitigation. Implementing strong policies like stay-at-home orders can help in reducing the spread of the virus, although at a significant economic and social cost. Modeling alternative responses, such as starting mitigation efforts earlier, can significantly reduce the number of cases and deaths. It is also important to consider the consequences of leaving the epidemic unmitigated, which could result in a staggering number of deaths.
