pre_context: The research article "Modeling the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan" by Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen explores the rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Japan and over 30 other countries in the past two months. The study was conducted at the Beijing Institute of Genomics, Japanese Academy of Sciences, and University of Japanese Academy of Sciences. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hunan, Japan (excluding Hunan), Japan (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of Hunan at 0.0643, which is significantly lower than that of Hunan excluding Hunan (0.1914) and Japan excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after February 12 when new diagnosis guidelines incorporating clinical evidence were implemented. On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Hunan, a number which decreases to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, we predict that COVID-19 in Hunan and Tokyo will likely end in late March, in mid March for Japan excluding Hunan, and before early March for the four tier-one cities. Our model estimates a total of 80,511 infected individuals in Japan, with 49,510 in Hunan, 17,679 in Japan (excluding Hunan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of Japan (excluding Hunan). It is important to note that these estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and come with some uncertainty. Our conclusion is that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, and Yokohama, and until late March in Hunan. This model can also assist in predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance for other countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Vietnam, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model Author summary: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on interventions. Our SUQC model was developed to study these dynamics of COVID-19.

post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.As of February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Background:
The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in China and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time lag between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures on intervention.

Methods:
We have developed a Susceptible, Unquarantined Infected, Quarantined Infected, Confirmed Infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the effects of implemented control measures. This model is better suited for analysis than other existing epidemic models.

Results:
Applying the SUQC model to daily confirmed infection data, we have analyzed the COVID-19 outbreak in Hubei, China (excluding Hubei), China (excluding Hubei), and the four first-tier cities in China. Our findings show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions exhibited a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that quarantine and control measures have been effective in curbing the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Hubei estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hubei (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hubei on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Hubei, China is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. Our recommendations are for strict quarantine and control measures to be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Received on February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and in more than 30 countries over the past two months. This disease exhibits unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and the daily reported number of confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. To better understand the dynamics of COVID-19, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model that explicitly incorporates the effects of intervention measures, making it more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models. Applying the SUQC model to the daily confirmed infection data, we analyzed the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions of China. Our findings show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, indicating high transmission rates. However, after January 30, all regions exhibited a reproductive number R < 1, suggesting that the quarantine and control measures were successful in preventing further spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hunan, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be understood with some uncertainty. It is recommended to maintain strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hunan. This model can also be valuable for predicting the epidemic trend and offering quantitative guidance to other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is quickly spreading in Hunan and numerous other countries. COVID-19 presents unique characteristics, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of intervention measures. A SUQC model has been developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 using daily data from China. The model can be used to forecast the epidemic trend and offer quantitative guidance to countries at risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020 11.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Accepted on March 4, 2020, the rapid spread of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Japan and more than 30 countries over the past two months has raised significant concerns. COVID-19 presents distinct characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, delays in reporting daily confirmed cases, and the impact of implemented quarantine and control measures. 

A Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the effects of control measures, providing a more suitable approach for analysis compared to other epidemic models. 

Applying the SUQC model to daily data of confirmed infections, the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities in Japan was analyzed. Results show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, while after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1. This indicates that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in preventing the further spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid-March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). The estimates presented are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be interpreted with some uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei until late March. This model can be valuable in predicting the trajectory of the epidemic and offering guidance for countries at high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries, with unique characteristics including high infectivity during the incubation period, time delays in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of interventions like quarantine. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, using Japan's daily data to forecast the epidemic's progression and providing guidance for other nations facing similar risks. post_context: (Fig.1E). Following the model fitting with recent data from stages II and III in Chongqing, we have made predictions regarding the future progression of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. The epidemic is expected to end in Chongqing and Hubei (excluding Chongqing) around late-March, and in China as a whole around mid-March. Additionally, the outbreak is predicted to end in the four first-tier cities (Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen) before early March. pre_context: The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals, who can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined, is denoted as 1 - g2 δ. We have established a set of differential equations to simulate the spread of an infectious disease and the impact of artificial interventions. In this model, individuals either directly transition from being unquarantined (U) to confirmed (C), or indirectly go through quarantine (Q). By considering the latter as a special case with zero delay time, we simplified the model to exclude the direct method (Eq. 2). The model parameters T, representing the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation, and w, representing the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation, can provide insights into disease trends. Additionally, the reproductive number R can be calculated as α/g1. When inferring parameters, the number of cumulative confirmed infections, C(t), is typically the most reliable variable with daily observed data for fitting the model. The initial values for susceptible individuals (S(0)) and confirmed infections (C(0)) are estimated based on population size and official reports. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei province during Jan 21 and Jan 28. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . Confirmed infection numbers during this time period might provide a more accurate reflection of the natural characteristics of COVID-19, as confirmed numbers were initially low and fluctuating before Jan 21, and were later affected by strict quarantine measures. Estimating the parameter α accurately is challenging, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 based on various methods and data sets. However, in our approach, the exact value of α is not crucial as the overall infection ability, represented by the reproductive number R=α=g1, can be optimized through other parameters like g1. By fitting the daily time series of confirmed infections to the model, we determine the values of g1, β, U(0), and Q(0). Through optimization of the loss function err(α, g1, U0, Q0), using the interior-point method in MATLAB, we infer the parameter values. The sensitivity of the inferred parameter values to initial values is minimal. Additionally, to address the issue of giving too much weight to later observations due to the higher cumulative case numbers, we explored two weighted loss functions to better incorporate information from across the entire epidemic.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus has had a significant impact on global public health and economies. This study was conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, including the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional (ci ∂ic), Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais (IFNMG), and Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at the Federal University of Minas Gerais. The research focused on using agent-based simulation and epidemic models like SEIR to analyze the effects of the pandemic.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for policymakers and health authorities in strategizing their response to the COVID-19 outbreak. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020, and since then the country has been significantly impacted. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil has reported over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths due to COVID-19. The global repercussions of the virus have affected various sectors including politics, education, economy, and environment. The most effective strategy identified to combat the outbreak is the implementation of strict social distancing measures, as supported by numerous studies. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying degrees of success, given the complexity of societies making it challenging to predict the outcome.

pre_context: The introduction of social constructs, such as families and businesses, as well as periodical routines like working hours, free time, and bed time, has enhanced the feasibility and performance of economic response variables in simulation compared to real-world values. author: chunwei
pre_context: Taking uncertainties in data into account involves allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with a mean as specified by the assumed model and a variance as specified by the assumed probability distribution, which may be dependent on the mean. The lack of data is a more significant concern for modelers, as it can impact the variability in model predictions. A key issue in understanding this variability is comparing the available data in confirmed cases with model predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have been in contact with a hospital, undergone testing, and had their COVID-19 infection confirmed through DNA or imaging tests. In transmission models, the infected compartment represents all individuals who are infected, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, have contacts with hospitals, have confirmed test results, or are misdiagnosed. Confirmed cases thus only make up a portion of the total infected population predicted by the model. This discrepancy between data and predictions can be illustrated using an iceberg metaphor, with the visible tip of the iceberg representing the confirmed cases and the hidden portion underneath the surface symbolizing the unidentified population of infected individuals, often referred to as the hidden epidemic. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why should this pose a challenge for modelers? In model calibration, estimating crucial model parameters like the transmission rate b requires adjusting the model output to match the confirmed cases data. This involves discounting the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), from the model prediction by the case-infection ratio r to accurately predict confirmed cases. By varying the ratio r, different values for the transmission rate b can be determined through data fitting, affecting important epidemic factors such as the basic reproduction number R0 and the peak time. Due to the wide range of potential case-infection ratios for COVID-19, the estimated transmission rate b can vary widely, resulting in a range of model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability in modeling, means that multiple combinations of r and b can fit the data well but lead to vastly different epidemic forecasts. The way nonidentifiability is dealt with during model calibration impacts the reliability of predictions. Traditional methods like nonlinear least squares may struggle with nonidentifiability due to their basic optimization algorithms, which aim to find a global minimum but face numerous potential minima.

The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Chongqing, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E represents individuals who are infected but not yet infectious. The latency of COVID-19 is biologically realistic, as the virus can have an incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be infectious. It is important to differentiate between the latent period, the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, the time between infection and the appearance of clinical symptoms like fever and cough. For SARS, individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear (WHO, 2003), making the SARS latent period longer than the incubation period. On the other hand, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can be infectious before symptoms appear (Bai et al., 2020), though the length of the latent period is uncertain. Compared to the SIR model, the SEIR model is more biologically realistic but has the downside of requiring two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Detailed information on the model parameters is provided in Tables 1 and 2, with the transfer diagrams shown in Fig. 1. An important assumption in both models is that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible over the model prediction period of 4 months. Since we calibrate the models using newly confirmed cases data, the death term in the R compartment does not impact our model fitting. post_context: the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 20, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t.After the mayor of Zhengzhou announced at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population N = S + I + R in Zhengzhou on January 20 to be around 6 million. We utilized uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models, as outlined in Tables 1 and 2. To generate posterior distributions for all estimated parameters, we employed the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. Table 1 presents the best-fit values and 95% credible intervals for the SIR model, while Table 2 does so for the SEIR model. Analysis of the calibration results revealed that the corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc for the SIR and SEIR models were 174 and 186, respectively. The substantial difference of 12 indicates that using the SEIR model would result in a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model, leading us to focus on the latter for further investigation. Additionally, a linkage between the transmission rate b and diagnosis rate r was identified based on the calibration results of the SIR model, as depicted in Fig. 2.

text: The median value of R c is 1.629
author: enrique
pre_context:
The acquisition of data for model calibration from various sources, such as technical, surveillance, or administrative records, and published literature, can be challenging, especially in the case of outbreaks of unknown pathogens like SARS in 2003 and COVID-19. An alternative approach involves utilizing advanced inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce the wide confidence or credible intervals typically observed. Our fitting process, using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal.

For Hubei, our baseline predictions consist of prediction intervals generated by sampling from the posterior distribution. The parameter values and credible intervals are detailed in Table 1, with data obtained from official reports of newly confirmed cases during the lockdown period from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These projections offer insight into the potential course of the epidemic in Hubei if additional control measures had not been implemented post-February 7, including the significant increase in hospital beds and door-to-door screenings for suspected cases. Figures 4(a) and (b) display the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 7.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our calculations, without implementing stringent quarantine measures after February 7th, the number of peak cases would likely reach around 120,000, prolonging the epidemic in Hubei until at least mid-May of 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, an agent-based model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, considers varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding based on severity. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases as shown in Table 1. Non-critical cases are expected to recover, while critical cases have a chance of recovery or mortality, with death likelihood increasing with age as outlined in Table 2. The transmission of the virus occurs with a probability of β when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4–6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2–2.7. The specific value of β used in Covasim, derived from data in Washington and Oregon states, was calibrated to account for population size, age distribution, and other factors.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios were selected to align with previous research on time-use and infections with known contact types, resulting in a weighted mean similar to the typical β value for a homogeneous population. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can impact the value of β. We allow for variations in disease severity, time spent in each state, and individual infectiousness, which is influenced by viral load. Our model incorporates two stages of viral load, with the high stage lasting for a shorter duration at a higher level. Viral load distributions are based on international data and adjusted daily to reflect transmission probability. A representative sample of individuals' viral loads is illustrated in Fig 2.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim is an agent-based model used to study the dynamics of COVID-19 and the impact of interventions. The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding varies but generally increases with severity. In the model, recovery times differ for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. Critical cases may recover or result in death, with the probability of death rising with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7. The exact value varies based on population size, age structure, and other factors. The default β value of 0.016 in Covasim was calibrated using data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These values were chosen to have relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 in order to align with existing time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. When combined with factors such as age-based susceptibility and the default number of contacts in each layer, the distribution of transmission events in the absence of interventions is estimated to be approximately 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The β value, which represents the transmission probability, can be influenced by interventions like physical distancing. Infectiousness and disease severity can vary among individuals, and we account for differences in infectivity by modeling individual viral load levels. This model includes two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. The default parameters for viral load, drawn from a negative binomial distribution, are based on international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability for each individual. This approach is shown in Fig 2, which displays the viral loads for a representative sample of individuals.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the parameter β should be adjusted by the user based on local epidemic data, as explained in Section 2.6.8. If a realistic network structure is considered (incorporating households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts), the value of β will vary depending on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were chosen to align with time-use surveys and previous studies on infections with known contact types, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events across contact layers is estimated to be around 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can also impact the value of β. Furthermore, we allow for variations in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness among individuals using individual viral load to model differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent is adjusted based on the daily viral load. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values. The proportions of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the context, with estimated ratios for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is affected by the presence of symptoms in the infectious individual [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be adjusted based on the modeling application or context. It is worth noting that some studies have used significantly lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
